parts.text: Although this is the in looks and I'm going to have a
conversation with Dean Davis for visible lives
An Oral History Project at the New York Public Library. It is
Thursday February twenty sixth two thousand and fifteen and
this is being recorded at the end of Haskell Braylon Talking Book Library
in New York City. Dean welcome.
Right here my domain is Mary Dean as I told you before
and I prefer to be called in.
All right that's exactly what we're doing. So why don't you start off and tell us
more about where you've come from something about yourself
. OK You know I was born in Pennsylvania and I lived there all
through college and good college and.
I will talk about you know my disability is late
onset in my early sixty's I'll try to post with retinitis pigmentosa
which is loss of peripheral vision. It usually starts
with last night vision which I don't have I can still go out at night and eyes still
see. But I have in the end I'm now seventy three so in
the last ten years I've lost all my peripheral vision and it's
also. Come from the bottom and the top So like if
I can only see. If people are close to me I
basically see them from the neck up if. When I
go to any extent I can still go to films and that because I can still read I
still have central vision and because they started so late in life.
They are hoping and they're thinking that I may retain some central vision
. Most people with disability. Go on by the time
they're thirty or forty I also have another condition
which is called a macular pucker and both guys. And I
will explain all of that and what's going on with that as later on but also go back to my
child.
So I was born had something and I went to school through
high school and then I went to undergraduate school in it and state
university I graduated in one thousand sixty three. I
was a good student especially through high school and so on.
And in college.
I could probably work harder at night but I was a
good student.
But I always felt I did a lot of reading and I have and then after that I also have a
master's degree and a law degree so I'll explain that my whole life that I went
to school I did a lot of schooling and I did a lot of reading but
. I always felt like I was a slow reader
. Compared to other people.
And. People said well why don't you take a reading class
and I never did that I just had a sense that there was something
wrong or that that wasn't really going to help me.
And. I was always very thorough I got good grades
but I took it seemed to me a longer time than other good students
I mean students who weren't so interested or something that's a different story but other good students it seemed
like they would could do things faster than I. So anyway
after I graduated from Penn State in one thousand sixty three my
first career was a secondary school teacher. Public schools my
first two years I taught in New Jersey and that was very rewarding
very place called Scotch Plains New Jersey. I had. High school
students Senior High School
. Because in those days they had junior high and high school so I was
in the high school mostly eleventh and twelfth graders. My first two years and
I really enjoyed that. You know I had been
reading different things like different classes but the more advanced
students I had the reading in addition to very
thin you know Mark Twain and different things like that so it was interesting
. Then after those two years I applied to graduate school
and I was accepted at Northwestern which is in Illinois so I
went there just for one year.
Prime ministers. And again
. It was you know I I did all I got my
masters and everything but I would say it was more the student rather than a
student. There.
Are. B.B. parse it was good enough but again I
always felt like slower than everybody else.
And I mean I didn't know why exactly.
OK So then after that I taught in Illinois for a
couple of years I got a job at a very good high school it's called your high
school is in the world there were two schools at that time the old school
was in Winnetka Illinois and a new school was in Northbrook Illinois and I taught in the new school which
was it was it was a very wealthy area and the school is like a
college campus. They had all these buildings and everything and it is very prestigious
it's people who are in secondary education in the United States know that Nutri year it's
like other good schools Gross Point Michigan as far as Dale New York you know I think
places like that. And some in California. So.
Again I was there for a couple of years. And then.
I did a ducktail up to Minneapolis for one year
because my mother was living there at the time and she was ill so I went up
and I actually got a job you know I sometimes stayed in
Illinois because I really liked it but I was helping out with her and she and ended up living to be
ninety but that's it.
So I was there for a year in the Minneapolis I got a job in the
Minneapolis schools and after that first year
. There the following
year they asked people who might be interested in working the
next year with. A couple of about six teachers from the Minneapolis public
schools far from the same St Paul schools. And a
. Lot of professors at the University of Minnesota to
develop a curriculum for inner city students so I thought that sounded
very interesting and I apply not thinking having only been there one year that I
would be you know chosen but actually less chose so.
I saw in those days there was a magazine called the Saturday Review
literature. And I saw in an ad in the back of that for
a course at Berkeley Kalin University of California Berkeley for the
summer in. I don't know what they called it exactly then
it might they might have called it African-American history or something like that but I
thought well gee if I go back out there for the summer and take that course I would have
material to bring back you know for this. Project in
many other schools. So I did I went out to Berkeley and it was
. Really a wonderful course.
Professor I think he had come. From Colombia
and then he was he stayed at Berkeley for a couple of years and then he ended up at Harvard
he established an American studies program didn't want to call it
just he didn't want it designated narrow narrowly so
. But anyway he was a wonderful teacher and.
He ended up liking California so much and I all this is where my big
question mark is because I would have been a great project in Minnesota
and I had coming out there to get material and to go back and the Minnesota Public schools were great
because they had a lot of follow through they would have an interesting very liberal
progressive I guess you call it more and they really
followed through whereas in Berkeley in the public schools high school not the
university. There was all kinds of stuff going on you know interesting
programs and stuff but I'm not so sure there was always the follow through that it was and
so but in any case I liked California and this was
Berkeley in the late sixty's one nine hundred sixty nine
. And in the seventy's it was very very interesting there. So I ended up
staying there. So I got a job and this was where I
taught the longest and it was a. Small community and
again a wealthy community. In the middle of Oakland.
California right it's like a one mile square is called Piedmont. And.
Well the first year I actually did long term substitute teaching in the Oakland public schools
. I lived in Berkeley.
But I taught in the open public schools long term substitute and
after this course I was interested I took a course through someone
else not the only African-American history but this was of course in racism. It
was very interesting and. The teacher. Oh he
only if he was a black. Very radical
type person
. But working within the system rather than the Black Panthers were there in Berkeley at the
time but he was working within the system. But he only admitted white people to his
class. And the reason for that was. For to teach and
we were all races because not because we were bad people but we were raised in a racist
society and that's something that I understood from then until now which a
lot of people don't want to. I admit that there is some. Racism because
you know I can I can tell you when I have reactions to things and stuff like that that's not it.
I don't need to be a bad thing but it's something where I have consciousness
but if I say to somebody a friend or you you know you they do something and
it's an attitude they don't like to hear that because they don't quite understand you know they think it's a heavy criticism
and it isn't is just like pointing out well this is what it is. Well anyway.
So the reason I ended up teaching in Piedmont which was an all
white area in the middle of it and a lot of the people who lived there was a
wealthy area. They ran a lot of the things in Oakland but the head of the
paper called The Oakland Tribune and the person who was the head of that
the whatever they call it they have an editor in chief but the owner whatever he lived in
Pismo and the reason this professor said. You
look like you paint U.K.'s in the white community. So
your role would be more helpful in changing attitudes.
If you go there and try to change attitudes of people who have power
rather than doing missionary work as you know in quotes pointed out
you treat teaching in the Oakland schools so I got a job there
and it was really. As far as my colleagues and my teacher
colleagues there some of the best friends I've ever had in my life I don't know.
If I inserted that anything but but I mean in the
community there were some Yeah I would say it was at the time
considerable drawback because it was some threat there because being surrounded
by a larger community.
But anyway I was there for eleven years.
And. The sentence.
None of this has anything to do with my own work so far except
that I'm just saying that my whole life I've done a lot of reading I was an English
teacher. There's you know you have
to do a lot of writing there's a lot of correcting of
compositions in the you know things like that. So I've always been dealing with
. The written word and so on. Unfortunately as I said before
I don't have peripheral vision but I can still read at this point and use the computer
. I wear glasses for reading but that's different you know. So
anyway. So I ended up there eleven years and my teacher colleagues were
wonderful. The ones in Illinois were too but I was only there two years. But these are some of the best
friends I don't ever have and I still love now that we have in the in the
technological age with computers and everything I am in touch with a lot of those people and
I don't travel as much as I think I have been. Haven't been
back there for about ten years because with my vision
. Changing I'll talk about that later about the limitations on travel and so
on. But. OK so.
Then I took a year's leave of that sentence and I came back east and my
idea was. To stay in New York for one year and then
a part of now one year to stay in your part of the year. And then spend the
rest of the year in Europe because when I was in college at Penn State I studied we
had a semester. I actually studied in France for one
semester. And I had also been back. TO EUROPE.
A. Couple of times I know in one thousand seventy two I actually went on
the way home in the summer and traveled around to different places. So anyway I
wanted to go back. But I ended up staying in New York the whole year
. It just worked out that way and
. It was a really good year. But.
And I met someone that I ended up marrying but. I wasn't really
sure. At that point whether I wanted to get married so I still had my teaching
job in California so I went back for a year I taught and then. This person
whose name is Joe and I decided to get married so I came back the next year and
I resigned my job there and. Joe
and I got married. And first I was thinking I might teach in the New
York City school system. But
. Actually when I applied I mean. They were
giving me sort of a hard time. I felt like they were going to give me any credit
for almost what.
Seventeen eighteen years teaching experience plus a bachelor's and master's degree
was like I was going to start from the basic or something it was like I was off a
lot of red tape and everything so I thought you know you know and maybe
after all those years I was the students were changing as the years went on
they were even though the schools where I taught I always felt that it was
challenging but I was only a substitute there one year that was
somewhat challenging as far as
It was it was a different kind of environment than the other schools where there
was a mostly all white and college oriented but there was kind of a
verbal sparring with the students were doing with the teachers and stuff.
And after about eighteen years I was a little tired.
So anyhow.
So when this when the New York's schools for giving me such a problem. It's
OK. I just
design it. Let me think about something else. So my husband was working
and I had always thought possibly of going to law school because my
there are lawyers in my family my grandfather in my home who were lawyers in
Wisconsin which is where my parents were from originally.
And. So I thought about that and but I was in
my forty's by this time and I didn't know if I wanted to spend all the money in the time in the effort
to go to law school so I decided to take a paralegal course at N.Y.U.
first to see how I went and I did really well
. So instead of going
to law school I thought I got a job at one of those big firms in Manhattan
supported paralegal they called me and I did that for about a year and a half
. And you know I kind of felt like nobody knew.
Really my background that I had been a teacher a professional person and stuff and some of
those people it was a very prestigious firm and some of the lawyers there are much smarter than I am but some
of the more I think I have.
But I felt like I was being treated like a second class citizen condo so I
thought well. Maybe I should go to Lowe's because you know I'd like to know and I thought
maybe I could do it. So I applied. And I decided I had a couple
examples but I decided to since I was living here in New York I was had some acceptance
is out of state but that wasn't that practical so I decided to go
the ones where in New York that accepted me to go to Brooklyn last so I went there and I
was there three years graduated. And.
I ended up. Working in the court system
for that which it really was good for my personality
because I was behind the scenes I was a little wanting to get
away from being one teacher you're out there all the time and you're in lowering in your going out
reaching out but actually I'm more I mean believe it or not talking so much and
kind of more of an introvert. It combination
but. I like to be by myself a lot and be quiet and so on and
so working for judges in New York State court system.
I did mostly research and writing. I'm a good writer researcher and first
I was in the appellate court which is all research and writing and the proclaimed second
department that was for about five and a half years and then I moved to the
circuit square in Brooklyn which is. When people died of
state's trust and they have some adoptions in the service court although most of them are
in the county court and you know things like that. So there I was doing research and writing
for the judges the judge in the appellate court there were like fifteen to twenty judges you for three
different ones you know depending on the day. Whatever case you
were working on it could be for any of the judges where it was in the service core there
was. Initially in Brooklyn it was one surrogate they call it
that they call the judge but. Later on there were two because there are many
there's more volume in Brooklyn than any other county each county in the state has.
One trial court which is in New York called the Supreme Court and then they have the
lower courts and in each county sixty two counties there is a circuit
court in each county also but the only one that had two judges to service
was the one in Manhattan. Until. One has a
really big money cases in tax cases and stuff like that but there's a lot of
money in some of those cases but not as many but there's more volume because the the
. Well that's there. I'm actually talking more about the
appellate division. But even in the Brooklyn service court there's a lot of volume
. So anyway they decided to make the wrong
thing to have to do to surrogates also. So after I was here
for a while change and I was there I was in the service for
thirteen years. But three of those years I went to the Bronx
Service Corps so I was an appellate division
second department five years that I was in the service work for a number of years then I
went to the product service work for three years and I came back to Brooklyn. So
altogether I was in the courts working for an eighteen and a half years
. So I retire at sixty seven. And.
Anyhow the point of all of this is an awful lot to talk a lot talk about
. Just.
Back up what I was saying I just from reading in my life
and. It's just amazing because
apparently I always had this. And because
Britain is pigmentosa is.
Hereditary. So I don't know anyone in my family who had
it. My father died young. He was in his fifty's mid
fifty's. He was not accepted into the second world
war because he had flat feet and something about his vision.
He wore glasses but you know it was never explained that he had
any idea. So maybe he would have developed something like this later I don't
know where it comes from exactly my mother lived to be ninety
and. She was still driving at ninety
. Basically my mother lived in Wisconsin so it wasn't as
busy as a new city or anything in Green Bay Wisconsin. But she
drove during the day mostly.
And my mother was athletic as I'm not and she played into her at the
summer her ninetieth year she was still playing golf with her golfing friends who were like
in their seventy's twenty under which is my age in there but
you know.
As far as I know she wore glasses but I mean she never had any. She could still
drive so I don't know you know I don't think she she had her eyes checked you know every
year. Your grandson and me gave that answer Grinch who still like to
see him. OK so anyhow
. Around my early
sixty's as I said. I started that's when I started there
the impact started this thread and I guess the toes and I started noticing
when I was taking the subways and so on that. I
was always telling my doctor at the time it was not you know
that's another frustration with all these awful knowledge as. I was telling him you
know when I'm in the subway when I'm walking and then all of a sudden
especially. You know my left side. I don't seem to see
people until they are like almost past me. And I'm kind of concerned
about that and he said. Well you're just getting older
. They seem to say
so. That went on for maybe a year
or two. But. You know I didn't see him that
often maybe once every six months or so and each time for a year or so I was
saying you know I'm still having this problem I don't seem to see people until they're in
front of me and he would give me the same answer. And he never
did. It turned out. He never gave me a field test and
I didn't even know what a field test was so in
. January of two thousand and five
. I was still driving. I I always drop the other thing about driving though all
my life. I always notice that. You know of
course you have mirrors you know we're very modern rear view mirror and mirrors
on the side of the automobile and you can see if you look at the near cars
coming up but I always notice that. I seem to have a blind
spot. And I didn't really know or think that much about it I thought
everybody had that if I say over I'll be driving and I would look in
the side mirror and I would see a car coming up. But then I never
saw the car when it was beside me now I don't know if other people do or not but I
always turn my head all the way around to make sure that there
wasn't a car in there before.
Say if I were going to make a turn or change lanes or anything like that and I thought of this
afterward after I was diagnosed that I always had to do that term when we have to make
sure you know
. And once they're up here if they're passing me I could see them you know when they're in their
past. My whatever my side view so
that's that was another thing. Well anyway. Where was I so. Jane
you know we still I still drove I actually had given up my car because you don't really need
a car in New York City and it was just you know eating up money parking it
somewhere or you know so I had actually given my car out
probably in the early two thousand and then I rented a
car in two thousand and four that was the last time I drove to go to Pennsylvania for a high school class
reunion. And. Then.
I didn't notice any problem right. But in January of two thousand that was October of
two thousand and four January two thousand and five.
In the meantime I haven't met my other needs in
one thousand nine hundred eighty.
I'll get back to the art of problems management nine hundred ninety eight. I
was diagnosed with late onset retinitis pigmentosa which is.
A. Joint you know osteoarthritis
is just. Maybe your knee one knee or this or that or you know with with
the phones or something rubbing together etc and I'm seventy three now and I don't
really suffer too much from them. Retinitis Pigmentosa.
I'm sorry I'm
just sorry I was in one thousand nine hundred eighty I was diagnosed with late onset rheumatoid
arthritis for about a year and a half I was in
severe pain. It mostly affected my
shoulders. It started in my knees but I had a few
shots of the whatever that is that you know prints are something of a
steroids kind of stuff and that kind of cleared up by my
ankles my wrists my hands my shoulders in
particular were just it was so painful I couldn't sleep at night
. I lost you know a lot of weight not in a good way
to lose weight and. After a year and
a half.
The F.D.A. approves a new but they're called biologic drugs
and my doctor my rheumatologist Hospital for Special Surgery he's very
very good. He decided to try and bring it with
me which is an injectable thing and at first I was like No I'm not
squeamish about injections which is a good thing but you have to inject
it first I don't even remember how many times but as time went on. Within
six months. A year and a half of severe pain. I still work I
still went on the subway and people they can't see things like that and not talk
about how they can't see my blindness either but when I had too much worth writing
I was on a very crowded. Four or five train from Union
Square in Manhattan into Brooklyn every morning just packed and I could
barely. Hold on. I couldn't reach up my shoulders for something to hold
on to anything you know. But people couldn't see that I was.
They didn't realize that I you know had something so that was
very hard. And. When I get back
and forth to work they knew it work they knew with the chords. That I was having these
problems and they were pretty good about it I mean it was OK if I
I tried to be there on time but if I was if I were a little late it was OK He
was fine about it and stuff because I was a good worker.
I stayed late to you know times which was kind of good in a way as in you're not in the rush
hour it. Yeah yeah a lot of time
we had to stay anyway till seven to get our work done and then I used to try to stay in my
office at the court rather than taking it home whereas when I was teaching I used to take
things that are you know had a nice offices roomy and stuff.
Anyway so after your new era I started taking Enbrel and within six
months I was not experiencing any pain it was really good but I took
that.
Gradually having to give myself the shots less and less
. For about five years and then. When I
started having problems with my vision rheumatoid arthritis and vision
problems are somewhat related because there's a thing about
inflammation and everything. In fact one of the seminars within the last year the
foundation for a private seminar. Dr name condemn
came and he reiterated that point that we which were right as you know there's
sometimes a connection. So. Anyway
. My rheumatologist decided to take me off the air and
just in case because it was new and just in case there was any kind of connection because I had not
yet been diagnosed with with that nice big windows. So he
did and he said you know he could give me something else well that was two thousand five
July. I never had to take anything again for the rheumatoid arthritis it's
in complete remission. So that's a good that's a good news however
If.
I had a choice between that were losing my vision I would
choose if I could have only one I would choose rheumatoid arthritis because it was treatable
. So anyway so then what happened
in January two thousand and five. I was
. Coming home. From work and.
I was on my blog and this woman was coming up to
me she had two dogs on leashes and they were kind of spreading out one dog
was going to the left and one dog was going to the right and I love animals I'm a
real advocate of animals and stuff and. In fact
. In the New York City Bar I was on the Animal Law Committee for a while and everything I'm real
serious about saving our. Cats and dogs and farm animals
and in fact most of my will and I are going to
charitable things for them but. So
and some for blindness to me but. To children you know
researching by light and other things too but anyway.
